review.title: Right Ideals of a Ring and Sublanguages of Science
review.abstract: Among Zellig Harris's numerous contributions to linguistics his theory of the sublanguages of science probably ranks among the most underrated. However, not only has this theory led to some exhaustive and meaningful applications in the study of the grammar of immunology language and its changes over time, but it also illustrates the nature of mathematical relations between chunks or subsets of a grammar and the language as a whole. This becomes most clear when dealing with the connection between metalanguage and language, as well as when reflecting on operators.

metadata.title: RIGHT IDEALS OF A RING AND SUBLANGUAGES OF SCIENCE

sections.text: Among Zellig Harris "numerous contributions to linguistics, his Theory of Languages of Science is probably one of the most underestimated works of recent years. However, not only has this theory led to some exhaustive and significant applications in the study of the grammar of immunology, but it also illustrates the nature of the mathematical relationships between chunks, or subsets of a grammar, and language as a whole. This is most evident when it comes to the connection between metalanguage and language, as well as when reflecting on operators. This paper attempts to justify the claim that the sublanguages of science are in an articulate algebraic relationship to the rest of the language in which they are embedded, namely that right-wing ideals are in a ring.
